repnme.cdata!:
China - Forest Resource Development and
            Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Forest Resource
            Development is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as
            likely, institutional development impact as sustainable,
            Bank performance as satisfactory, and borrower performance
            as satisfactory. The lessons learned form the project design
            and implementation include: 1) Close correlation from the
            borrower's priorities is the foundation of the project.
            2) The strong linkage of research and extension with
            planting activities was critical to technology transfer. 3)
            Centralized procurement of fertilizers and pesticides is not
            appropriate for multi-provinces forestry projects, where the
            project participants are widely dispersed. 4) Further study
            will be necessary to assess market condition and new
            policies such as logging ban related issues. 5) Watershed
            management will be more effectively carried out as
            integrated land management approach with treatments not only
            for forest zones. 6) Bank projects have raised awareness of
            the potential of production forestry.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Forest Resource Development and
            Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Forest Resource Development and
            Protection project is designed to enhance the productivity
            of forest resources, the efficiency of resource use, and the
            institutional capacity for sustainable management in the
            three major forest types in China: commercial plantations,
            watershed protection forests, and nature reserves. The
            project will: 1) expand the supply of commercial timber and
            pulpwood through establishment of 620,000 hectares of
            intensively managed plantations; 2) develop improved models
            for watershed management through establishment of 280,000
            hectares of protection forests; 3) enhance biodiversity
            conservation through improved management of nature reserves
            and natural forests; 4) strengthen the operating efficiency
            of technical support services in the forestry sector,
            particularly planting materials, research, and extension
            programs; and 5) strengthen the capacity of forest sector
            institutions in planning and management.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Forest Resource Development &
            Protections Project : report on analysis of FRDPP's
            impacts on environment

abstracts.cdata!:
Forest Resource Development and
            Protection Project (FRDPP) is the continuation of National
            Afforestation Project (NAP) and its major objectives are to
            establish intensive management plantation (IMP) and the
            multi-use protection forests (MFP), as well as to improve
            the management of natural reserves.  According to the
            preliminary evaluation of the natural conditions, economic
            development and environmental aspects in the project area
            and on the principle of achieving optimal benefits it has
            been decided that the project will be implemented in 16
            provinces with a total area of 780,000 hectares.

China - Forest Resource Development &
            Protections Project : report on analysis of FRDPP's
            impacts on environment
